data.title: US Judge Dismisses Indictment Against Huawei CFO Meng
data.description: WASHINGTON, December 3 (Sputnik) - A United States District Judge dismissed an indictment against Meng Wanzhou, the chief financial officer of Huawei Technologies Co, putting an end to a criminal sanctions case that has been straining US-China relations.

data.title: Primitive Microscopic Hair Tendrils on Brain Cells Are Crucial to Time Monitoring, Study Reveals
data.description: The results of the new research carried out by the team from the University of California may potentially open up new therapeutic methods of tackling mental and neurological disorders.

data.title: Russian Embassy Sends Note of Protest to UK Foreign Office Over Arrest of Russian Citizen
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - The Russian Embassy in London on Saturday sent a note of protest to the UK Foreign Office in connection with the arrest of a Russian citizen, demanding the admission of consular officers and a lawyer to the person in question.

data.title: Veteran Paleocon Urges Washington Not to Let Kiev Drag US Into Unwanted War With Russia
data.description: The United States and its allies have sent tens of billions of dollars’ worth of weapons to Ukraine over the past nine months, ignoring Moscow’s warnings that the arms flow escalates the conflict, and results in the uncontrolled spread of Western weaponry to terrorists and criminal groups across the planet.

data.title: Poll - Nearly 1 in 4 Germans Won't Buy Christmas Gifts Due to Inflation
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - Nearly a quarter of Germans say they will not purchase Christmas gifts this year due to rampant inflation, according to a representative poll conducted by the Institute for New Social Answers (INSA).

data.title: Uvalde Survivors File Lawsuit Seeking $27B From Police – As City Sues DA For Police Records
data.description: Survivors of the school shooting that claimed 21 lives in Uvalde, Texas are seeking billions as the local DA is sued for withholding information from internal affairs investigation into police failures.

data.title: Blast at Airfield Near Russia's Ryazan Kills 3 People, Injures 6 More: Emergency Services
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - Three people were killed and six more were injured as a fuel tanker caught fire at an airfield near the Russian city of Ryazan, the emergency services told Sputnik on Monday.

data.title: Norway Forks Out to Secure Subsea Cables in Lucrative Oil and Gas Industry
data.description: After several rounds of backfiring sanctions against Russian energy by Brussels, Norway became Europe's number one gas supplier, replacing Moscow. The windfall revenues result from Europe's largely self-inflicted energy crisis, which has proved the worst in decades, have sparked accusations of profiteering against Oslo from other European nations.

data.title: China Urges Australia to Stop Sending 'Wrong Signals' to Taiwan: Official
data.description: BEIJING (Sputnik) - Australia should adhere to the internationally recognized one-China principle and stop sending misleading signals to "separatist forces" on the island of Taiwan, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said on Tuesday.

data.title: US Prison Bureau 'Incompetence' Led to Mobster Whitey Bulger’s Jailhouse Murder - Watchdog
data.description: WASHINGTON (Sputnik) - The death of notorious mob boss James "Whitey" Bulger after a jail transfer was the result of bureaucratic incompetence and management failures at multiple levels of the US Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP), the Justice Department's Inspector General (OIG) said in a report.

data.title: Report: CIA Warned Turkey That Strikes Against Syria Threaten US Troops
data.description: Turkey has been bombing parts of Syria and Iraq since November 20, a week after a terrorist attack in Istanbul that the Turkish government says was carried out by Kurdish militants.

data.title: Syria's Idlib De-escalation Zone Attacked Twice in Past Day, Reconciliation Center Says
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - The Jabhat al-Nusra terrorist group (banned in Russia) shelled Syria's Idlib de-escalation zone twice over the past 24 hours, Major General Oleg Yegorov, deputy head of the Russian Defense Ministry's Center for Reconciliation of Opposing Sides in Syria, said at a briefing.

data.title: Russia Confident Demand For Its Oil to Remain Despite Price Cap: Embassy
data.description: WASHINGTON (Sputnik) - Russia has no doubt that its oil will continue to be in demand on world markets even after the introduction of the price cap, the Russian Embassy in the United States said.

data.title: Algeria Needs to Bring Legislative Acts to Common Standard Before Joining BRICS, Governor Says
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - Algeria needs to harmonize its legislation with BRICS nations before joining the group, which could further benefit the Algerian economy, the governor of the country's capital of Algiers, Mohamed Abdenour Rabehi, told Sputnik on Saturday.

data.title: Senegalese-American Singer Akon Comes Under Fire After Defending Kanye West’s Anti-Semitic Remarks
data.description: American rapper Kanye West has been subjected to criticism over the past two months after making anti-Semitic remarks on social media and in interviews. On Thursday, the 45-year-old artist continued making anti-Semitic comments during an appearance on the InfoWars show hosted by Alex Jones, arguing that he sees “good things about Hitler.”

data.title: JUST IN - England Enters World Cup Quarter-Finals with 3-0 Win Over Senegal
data.description: On Sunday English fans rejoiced as their football team cruised past Senegal into the World Cup quarter-finals with a 3-0 win.

data.title: Severed Body Parts of Andhra Woman Found in Drum
data.description: While the victim's identity has not been confirmed yet, police assume it could be the wife of the suspect.

data.title: White House against Trump's attack on the Constitution
data.description: White House Spokesman Andrew Bates Sunday said in a statement that "attacking the Constitution and all it stands for is anathema to the soul of our nation and should be universally condemned."

data.title: US Opens Probe Into Musk's Neuralink Over Animal Testing, Reports Say
data.description: WASHINGTON (Sputnik) - The Inspector General for the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) opened a probe into Elon Musk's Neuralink over employee complaints about animal testing, Reuters exclusively reported, citing documents the news agency reviewed and sources familiar with the investigation and company operations.

data.title: A 150,000 people petition urging the EU to protect the welfare of fish
data.description: A petition asking for new standards to protect the welfare of fish signed by more than 150,000 people, was handed on Monday to the European Commission. It comes ahead of a full revision of animal welfare legislation announced by the Commission in May 2020 as part of the EU farm and Fork strategy and Compassion in World Farming wants to ensure that farmed fish welfare standards are included.

data.title: Creation of ECOWAS Regional Force 'Critical to Addressing Security Gaps' in West Africa - Experts
data.description: After the recent Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) summit, the bloc's leaders announced the establishment of a peacekeeping force to provide security in the region. Sputnik has asked scholars and experts to speak about the context of the decision and its importance.

data.title: Russia Continues to Surpass Saudi Arabia, Iraq as India's Top Oil Supplier
data.description: India’s Foreign Minister S. Jaishankar indicated that New Delhi would not follow the G7’s cap on the price of Russian oil, which came into effect on December 5.

data.title: EU Likely to Impose Price Cap on TTF Gas Futures Before Year End, Von der Leyen Says
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - The European Union is likely to introduce a price cap for gas futures on the TTF, Europe's main trading hub for natural resources, before the end of 2022, with disagreements over the ceiling's level expected to be settled soon, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said on Wednesday.

data.title: US House Passes New 2023 Defense Spending Bill Valued at Nearly $850 Billion
data.description: The US House of Representatives on Thursday passed a new version of the 2023 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) that provides $847.3 billion in discretionary defense and energy-related funding, including $10 billion in security aid for Taiwan and $800 million for Ukraine.

data.title: Why Didn't Biden Swap Paul Whelan Convicted for Espionage in Russia?
data.description: Earlier this week, Russian businessman Viktor Bout, who spent 15 years in a US prison, was swapped for US WNBA basketball player Brittney Griner, who was arrested in Russia earlier this year. The deal did not involve Paul Whelan, presently serving a 16-year prison term in Russia for espionage.

data.title: US May Reportedly Halt Military Aid to Ukraine If Congress Fails to Agree on Budget Bill
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - The United States may be forced to halt providing assistance to Ukraine if Congress fails to pass full-year legislation to fund defense programs and other government operations, US media reported on Sunday.

data.title: At Least Nine Dead After Flood Hits Baptism Ceremony in Johannesburg - Reports
data.description: According to a recent report by the South African National Sea Rescue Institute, a total of 8 862 people drowned in South Africa between the years 2016 and 2021, which means 28 people drown in the country on a weekly average.

data.title: Hungary Slaps Down €18 Billion EU Aid Package for Kiev
data.description: Hungary has adhered to an independent position on Ukraine throughout the current crisis, owing to its difficult relationship with Kiev. The two countries have been engaged in a long-running dispute going back to the 2014 Ukrainian coup, which brought a nationalist government to power that has discriminated Ukraine’s ethnic Hungarian minority.

data.title: Europe Unable to Replace All of Russian Gas Supply With Other Sources, EU Energy Chief Says
data.description: WASHINGTON (Sputnik) - It is not possible for Europe to replace the entirety of its Russian gas supply with alternative sources, European Commissioner for Energy Kadri Simson said on Tuesday.

data.title: What to Do About Kanye West
data.description: How to respond to Kanye West? His business partners severed ties. Liberal media outlets resorted to cancel culture. Elon Musk gave the artist now known as Ye a second chance on Twitter, only to regret his magnanimity after Ye posted a graphic of a swastika intertwined with a star of David, and kicked him back off the platform.

data.title: From Lawyer to Chancellor: Scholz Marks 1st Year in Office as Polls Show Many Unhappy With His Work
data.description: One of the latest opinion polls shows that more than 50 percent of Germans are dissatisfied with Chancellor Olaf Scholz's work. In March, the figure stood at 39 percent.

data.title: Serbia to Consider Return of 1,000 Soldiers to Kosovo Under UNSCR 1244 - Office for Kosovo
data.description: BELGRADE (Sputnik) - The Serbian government will consider returning up to 1,000 troops of its security forces to Kosovo and Metohija under the United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 because of Pristina's controversial moves, Petar Petkovic, the head of Serbia's office for Kosovo and Metohija, said on Thursday.

data.title: Elon Musk's SpaceX Puts 40 Satellites of Rival Company OneWeb Into Orbit
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - Elon Musk's SpaceX has put 40 satellites of its rival in the sphere of space-based internet communications, OneWeb, into orbit, the company said on Thursday.

data.title: Photographer Involved in Balenciaga's 'Gimp Teddy Ad Campaign' Reports Death Threats
data.description: The photographer, Gabriele Galimberti, reportedly said that the vast majority of the threatening messages he received came from the United States.

data.title: Uruguayan paramilitary murderers sentenced to over 20 years in jail
data.description: Two members of Uruguay's infamous Death Squad have been handed down heavy prison sentences for their involvement in two murder cases, it was announced Friday in Montevideo.

data.title: Residential Bloc Explosion in Jersey, UK Kills One, 12 Missing, Reports Say
data.description: Residential Bloc Explosion in Jersey, UK Kills One, 12 Missing, Reports Say

data.title: China Completes First-Ever In-Orbit Rotation of Crews at Tiangong Station: Space Agency
data.description: BEIJING (Sputnik) - China's taikonauts held a successful in-orbit rotation of crews at the Tiangong space station for the first time in the country's history, the China Manned Space Agency (CMSA) said.

data.title: Suspected Murderer in Shraddha Walkar Case Used Cleaver to Dismember Body
data.description: Delhi Police arrested Aftab Ameen Poonawalla on 14 November under suspicion of killing and chopping up the body parts of his live-in partner Shraddha Walkar.

data.title: Burkina Faso Suspends Broadcast of French State-Owned RFI Radio
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - Burkina Faso's military government has suspended the broadcast of France's state-owned Radio France Internationale (RFI), accusing it of having released a message from a terrorist leader to intimidate the population of the West African nation, government spokesman Jean Emmanuel Ouedraogo said.

data.title: Poland's Krakow City Administration Reduces Working Hours to Save Energy, Reports Say
data.description: WARSAW (Sputnik) - Administration of the Polish city of Krakow decided to reduce its operating hours to save electricity, local media said on Monday.

data.title: Thousands of People Who Fled Boko Haram Attacks in Northeastern Nigeria Return Home, Officials Say
data.description: Terrorism and insurgent violence carried out by the terrorist organization Boko Haram* is one of the major drivers of insecurity across northeastern Nigeria and the Lake Chad Basin. As the Nigerian government has made strides in retaking and stabilizing large portions of the region, affected residents are gradually restoring their lives.

data.title: Glencore to Pay $180 Million to Cover Corruption Claims in DRC
data.description: Switzerland-based Glencore, one of the world's biggest commodity trading and mining companies, has a long history of international corruption. In May, the company admitted to bribing officials in multiple African states and South America following a wide-ranging investigation by US, British, and Brazilian authorities.

data.title: Neuralink: Is Symbiosis Between Human Brain & AI Worth the Pain and Risk?
data.description: Elon Musk's medical-device firm Neuralink has been caught in the crosshairs of the Inspector General for the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) over complaints about a hasty animal-testing process. What's Musk's brain implant project about and what is its real goal?

data.title: Argentina's VP Given 6 Years in Prison, Barred From Holding Public Office in Corruption Case
data.description: A three-judge panel sentenced Argentine Vice President Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner on Tuesday to serve six years in prison in a corruption trial that has engulfed much of the South American nation. A lifetime ban from holding public office was also handed down.

data.title: President Putin Takes Part in Online Meeting of Council for Civil Society and Human Rights
data.description: The council is holding a major meeting ahead of Human Rights Day, which is celebrated on December 10, commemorating the day when the United Nations adopted the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

data.title: President Putin Takes Part in Heroes of the Fatherland Day Commemoration
data.description: Heroes of the Fatherland Day is celebrated across the country on December 9, marking the day when the highest military decoration of the Russian Empire - the Order of St. George - was established.

data.title: Disabled Woman Files Rape Lawsuit Against Backstreet Boys Frontman Nick Carter, Reports Say
data.description: MOSCOW (Sputnik) - A woman with autism and cerebral palsy has accused the frontman of the US band Backstreet Boys, Nick Carter, of raping her more than 20 years ago, US media reported on Friday.

data.title: Fresh Attack On Voting Site in South-east Nigeria, Electoral Commission Says
data.description: In February 2023, Nigerian citizens will be casting their vote to choose a successor to President Muhammadu Buhari, whose second term is coming to end. Nigerians will also be casting their ballots in parliamentary and state elections. As elections draw near, attacks on election offices have been reported.

data.title: Moscow: West's Energy Suggestions Can't Address Industrialization Issues in Africa
data.description: In recent years, Western nations have put the transition to green energy at the top of the climate agenda, urging countries around the world to abandon traditional energy sources over the next few decades, and criticizing those who are hesitant to fully embrace the concept.

data.title: Elon Musk Hits Back at Kanye West After Rapper's 'Genetic Hybrid' Swipe
data.description: Since taking over Twitter in October, Elon Musk has been involved in ugly spats with some prominent personalities, including rapper Kanye West.
